This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Levi_Parham","to":"Levi Parham"}],"pages":{"47943121":{"pageid":47943121,"ns":0,"title":"Levi Parham","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2020}}\n{{Notability|music|date=November 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Levi Parham\n| image               =Monday Monday 03 07 2016 -18 (26200026446).jpg\n| image_size          = \n| landscape           = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt                 = \n| caption             =\n| birth_name          = \n| alias               = \n| birth_date          = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year unless the exact date is already WIDELY published, as per [[WP:DOB]] -->\n| birth_place         = \n| origin              = [[McAlester, Oklahoma]], United States\n| death_date          = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) -->\n| death_place         = \n| genre               = [[Blues music|Blues]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Country music|country]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n| occupation          = \n| instrument          = \n| years_active        = <!-- YYYY\u2013YYYY (or \u2013present) -->\n| label               = AGD Entertainment\n| associated_acts     = \n| website             =  {{URL|www.leviparham.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Levi Parham''' is an American singer/songwriter, recording artist from [[McAlester, Oklahoma]], United States.<ref name=\"agdentertainment\">{{cite web|url=http://www.agdentertainment.com/levi-parham/|title=Levi Parham \u2014 AGD Entertainment|website=Agdentertainment.com|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nLevi grew up in southeast [[Oklahoma]] listening to his father's large album collection, especially the [[blues]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Oklahoma musician Q&A: Levi Parham steers toward music with 'Avalon Drive' EP release|url = http://newsok.com/article/5372856|website = NewsOK.com|access-date = 27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Levi Parham Dredges Up the Past With 'Never Coming Home to Me'|url = http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/levi-parham-dredges-past-never-coming-home-me|website =Thebluegrasssituation.com|access-date = 27 December 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite web|title = Red Dirt Nation {{!}} Artist {{!}} Levi Parham|url = http://www.reddirtnation.com/View-Artist/ID/5224/Title/Levi-Parham|website =Reddirtnation.com|access-date = 27 December 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nParham began his career in 2013, self-releasing his first album, ''An Okie Opera''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Higgs|first1=Richard|title=Levi Parham \u2013 An Okie Opera|url=http://www.currentland.com/ViewArticle/1966/Default.aspx|publisher=Currentland.com|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref> Currentland Magazine named it one of the top [[Red Dirt (music)|Red Dirt]] albums of the year, alongside [[Samantha Crain]], [[Red Dirt Rangers]], and [[Jason Boland & The Stragglers|Jason Boland]].<ref name=\"auto\"/> He followed that release in 2014 with a six song EP,  ''Avalon Drive''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Oklahoma musician Q&A: Levi Parham steers toward music with 'Avalon Drive' EP release|url=http://newsok.com/article/5372856|newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]]|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Shelburne|first1=Craig|title=Levi Parham Relearns \"Never Coming Home to Me\"|url=http://www.cmtedge.com/2014/11/13/levi-parham-relearns-never-coming-home-to-me/|publisher=Cmtedge.com|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Anderl|first1=Timothy|title=Albums In The Stream: Levi Parham, Avalon Drive EP|date=9 December 2014 |url=http://ghettoblastermagazine.com/2014/albums-in-the-stream-levi-parham-avalon-drive-ep/|publisher=Ghettoblaster Magazine|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Mack|first1=Joe|title=Sound Advice: Levi Parham|url=http://www.currentland.com/ViewArticle/3168/Default.aspx|publisher=Currentland.com|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Matthews|first1=Cameron|title=LEVI PARHAM DREDGES UP THE PAST WITH 'NEVER COMING HOME TO ME'|url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/levi-parham-dredges-past-never-coming-home-me|website=Thebluegrasssituation.com|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gallacher|first1=Alex|title=Premiere: Levi Parham \u2013 Lola My Lovely (+ Song of the Day)|url=http://www.folkradio.co.uk/2014/11/premiere-levi-parham-lola-my-lovely/|publisher=Folkradio.co.uk|access-date=27 September 2015}}</ref>\n\nAfter touring the U.S., Parham met producer [[Jimmy LaFave]], who later signed him to Music Road Records<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.musicroadrecords.com/|title=Music Road Records|website=Musicroadrecords.com|access-date=10 May 2021}}</ref> in December 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Red Dirt Nation {{!}} Levi Parham on his current tour and upcoming album|url = http://www.reddirtnation.com/View-Article/AID/3054/Title/Levi-Parham-on-his-current-tour-and-upcoming-album|website =Reddirtnation.com|access-date = 17 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Jimmy LaFave comes full circle to Oklahoma with new album, Winter Wind concert|url = http://newsok.com/article/5450564|website =NewsOK.com|access-date = 17 December 2015}}</ref> Parham went into Cedar Creek Studios in [[Austin, Texas]] with LaFave to work on his next album. ''These American Blues'' was released on 24 June 2016 to favorable reviews.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Oklahoma singer-songwriter Levi Parham signs with Music Road {{!}} Music Road Records|url = http://www.musicroadrecords.com/oklahoma-singer-songwriter-levi-signs-with-music-road/|website =Musicroadrecords.com|access-date = 17 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.popmatters.com/levi-parham-these-american-blues-2495433131.html|title=Levi Parham \u2013 \"These American Blues\" (audio) (premiere)|date=1 May 2016|work=PopMatters|access-date=10 December 2017|language=en}}</ref> PopMatters Magazine said of the title song, \"It could stand as a rootsy election year anthem\", while Elmore Magazine said Parham \"sings with an occasionally world-weary, sometimes playful, but always powerful authority on America.\"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elmoremagazine.com/2016/06/music-news/levi-parham-parses-the-american-dream-on-his-powerful-new-record|title=Levi Parham Parses The American Dream On His Powerful New Record|date=1 June 2016|work=Elmore Magazine|access-date=10 December 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> ''These American Blues'' rose quickly on the [[Americana Music Association]] chart, topping out at No. 23.\n\nIn 2017, Parham toured Europe several times, with sold-out shows and festival dates in Spain, Netherlands, Italy, Germany, Switzerland, and Belgium, sharing stages with [[Jason Isbell]], [[Margo Price]], [[Chuck Prophet]], [[Jonny Lang]], [[Sam Outlaw]], [[Jim Lauderdale]], [[Hurray for the Riff Raff]], [[The Ben Miller Band|Ben Miller Band]], [[The Secret Sisters]], [[Jesse Dayton]], and more.\n\nIn June 2017, Parham was featured on a various artists' tribute to Mark Heard, ''Treasure of the Broken Land: The Songs of Mark Heard'', which showcased Heard's songwriting performed by [[Buddy Miller]], [[Rodney Crowell]], [[North Mississippi Allstars]], [[Over the Rhine (band)|Over the Rhine]], [[The Voice (U.S. season 8)|Sara Potenza]], and more.  While working on this project, Parham befriended [[Amy Helm]] and the two sang a duo together. Later that year, Parham went on the road as supporting act for Helm, with a tour up the US West Coast and Canada.\n\nSometime in early 2017 while touring through the South, Parham got the chance to visit a recording studio that was once owned and operated by [[The Swampers (band)|The Swampers]], the rhythm section that started the [[Muscle Shoals Sound Studio|Muscle Shoals Sound]]. While visiting with the engineer at the studio and touring the facilities, Parham got the idea to bring a crew of his Tulsa friends  to Muscle Shoals to combine both styles of music, and to get it all on tape. Parham assembled the line-up and in August 2017 he brought [[John Fullbright]], Dustin Pittsley,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dustinpittsley.com/|title=Dustin Pittsley Band &#124; The Official Site of the DPB|website=Dustinpittsley.com|access-date=10 May 2021}}</ref> [[Hard Working Americans|Jesse Aycock]], [[Dylan Golden Aycock]], [[John Moreland]], Lauren Barth,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.laurenbarth.com/ |title=Home |access-date=12 July 2022 |archive-date=20 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200220131511/http://www.laurenbarth.com/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> Paul Benjaman,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.paulbenjamanband.com/|title=Paul Benjaman Band|website=Paul-benjaman-band|access-date=10 May 2021}}</ref> and Michael Staub into Studio B at what is now called Portside Sound to cut a record. The session cut most songs live. The album was released in June 2018, ''It's All Good'', via Horton Records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/its-all-good-mw0003171697/releases|title=It's All Good - Levi Parham &#124; Releases &#124; AllMusic|access-date=10 May 2021|website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>  This Land Press called it \"A beautiful mixture of the Tulsa Sound and the Muscle Shoals history, resulting in an exciting blend of Southern vibes, soulful grooves, and mean guitar battles.\" while another review said, \"It's all good? No, It's all brilliant.\"\n\nIn 2018, Parham was featured in a video music series called \"Play It Loud\", focusing on Oklahoma bred music artists, which won a [[Heartland Emmy Awards|Heartland Emmy]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcalesternews.com/news/local_news/levi-parham-featured-in-emmy-winning-series/article_55e5b086-b376-5cb3-ba9d-1d4fea387eec.html|title=Levi Parham featured in Emmy-winning series|author=Adrian O'Hanlon III|website=McAlester News-Capital|language=en|access-date=8 January 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oklahoman.com/article/5602722/watch-oklahoma-music-series-play-it-loud-features-levi-parham-in-season-1-finale/|title=Watch: Oklahoma music series 'Play It Loud' features Levi Parham in Season 1 finale|date=2 July 2018|website=Oklahoman.com|language=en-US|access-date=8 January 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.potawatomi.org/play-it-loud-brings-home-an-emmy/|title=\"Play It Loud\" brings home an Emmy \u2022 Citizen Potawatomi Nation|date=1 September 2019|website=Citizen Potawatomi Nation|language=en-US|access-date=8 January 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n*''An Okie Opera'' (2013, self-released)\n*''These American Blues'' (2016, Music Road Records)\n*''It's All Good'' (2018, Horton Records)\n*''Sure, Okay, Great (2022, self-released)''\n\n===EPs===\n*''Avalon Drive'' (2014, self-released)\n\n===Various artist compilation album===\n* ''Treasure of the Broken Land: The Songs of Mark Heard'' (2017, Storm Weathered Records)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Parham, Levi}}\n[[Category:Blues musicians from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Living people]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"DeFord_Bailey","to":"DeFord Bailey"}],"pages":{"1007767":{"pageid":1007767,"ns":0,"title":"DeFord Bailey","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country musician (1899\u20131982)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2022}}\n{{good article}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = DeFord Bailey.JPG\n| caption         = Bailey in the 1970s\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1899|12|14}}\n| birth_place     = [[Smith County, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|1982|7|2|1899|12|14}}\n| death_place     = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.<ref name = \"JET\">{{cite journal|title=Grand Ole Opry Legend DeFord Bailey, 82, Dead|journal=JET|date=August 2, 1982|volume=62|issue=21|pages=53|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DLgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53|access-date=November 10, 2011}}</ref>\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = {{flatlist|\n* [[Harmonica]]\n* [[guitar]]<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\">{{cite web|url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/deford-bailey|title=Deford Bailey|publisher=[[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]]|access-date=December 10, 2021|archive-date=April 25, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190425094152/https://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/deford-bailey|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n* [[banjo]]<ref name = \"Samples\">{{cite web|title=DeFord Bailey: A Legend Lost/Samples of DeFord's music|url=https://www.pbs.org/deford/music/songs_samples.html|publisher=PBS|access-date=May 11, 2018 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512181609/http://www.pbs.org/deford/music/songs_samples.html |archive-date=May 12, 2018}}</ref>\n}}\n| genre           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[blues]]\n}}\n| years_active    = 1920s\u20131941\n| label           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Victor Recording Company|Victor]]\n* [[Bluebird Records|Bluebird]]\n* [[RCA Records|RCA]]\n}}\n}}\n'''DeFord Bailey Sr.'''<ref name=\"story\"/> (December 14, 1899 \u2013 July 2, 1982)<ref name=\"Wolfe\"/> was an American singer-songwriter and musician, who was considered the first African American [[country music]] and [[blues]] star. He started his career in the 1920s and was one of the first performers to be introduced on Nashville radio station [[WSM (AM)|WSM]]'s [[Grand Ole Opry]], and becoming alongside [[Uncle Dave Macon]] one of the programs most famous performers.<ref name=\"Quote\">{{cite web|url=https://www.countrymusichalloffame.org/hall-of-fame/deford-bailey|title=Deford Bailey|publisher=Country Music Hall of Fame|access-date=December 10, 2021|quote=In 1927, Hay spontaneously renamed the Barn Dance while introducing some of his down-home musicians on a WSM weekday evening broadcast following a classical music program. Countering the view that \u201cthere is no place in the classics for realism,\u201d Hay said, \u201c[W]e will present nothing but realism. It will be down to earth for the \u2018earthy.\u2019\u201d As if to illustrate his point, Hay introduced Bailey, whose \u201cPan American Blues\u201d recreated the whoosh of the L&N Railroad express train he had heard from his boyhood. In his introduction, Hay also said, \u201cFor the past hour, we have been listening to music largely from Grand Opera, but from now on, we will present \u2018The Grand Ole Opry.\u2019\u201d Thus Bailey and his musical cohorts helped to inspire the name of America\u2019s longest-running radio show.}}</ref> He was the first African-American performer to appear on the show, and the first performer to record his music in Nashville.<ref name=Tennessean/> Bailey played several instruments in his career but is best known for playing the [[harmonica]], often being referred to as a \"harmonica wizard\".\n\nBailey was born and raised in Tennessee, all his family played \"black hillbilly\" country and blue's music and he learned how to play the harmonica and mandolin while recuperating from polio as a young child.<ref name=Tennessean/>. He moved from New York to Nashville with relatives in his late teens and was a significant early contributor to Nashville's burgeoning music industry. Among the first generation of entertainers to perform live on the radio, his recorded compositions were well-known and popular.\n\nBailey toured and performed with [[Roy Acuff]] and many well-known country artists during the 1930s. But as a result of the 1941 royalties disagreement between [[Broadcast Music, Inc.]] (BMI) and [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers]] (ASCAP), he was fired by WSM and stopped making his living as an entertainer. Afterwards, he supported himself and his family by opening a shoe shining company and renting out rooms in his home. He returned to sporadic public performances in 1974 when he was invited to participate in the Opry's first Old-Timers show and in 2005 was posthumously inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]].\n\n==Early life==\nBailey was a grandson of slaves,<ref name = \"BlackHistory\">{{cite web |last=Johnston |first=Allen |title=A Black Star In Early Country Music |url=http://blackhistory.com/cgi-bin/blog.cgi?blog_id=196505&cid=10 |work=Black History |access-date=November 10, 2011 |date=March 1, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170311184138/http://blackhistory.com/cgi-bin/blog.cgi?blog_id=196505&cid=10 |archive-date=March 11, 2017}}</ref> and was born on December 14, 1899,<ref name=\"Wolfe\">{{cite encyclopedia|last=Wolfe|first=Charles K.|title=Deford Bailey (1899\u20131982)|url=http://tennesseeencyclopedia.net/entry.php?rec=50|encyclopedia=The Tennessee Encyclopedia|publisher=University of Tennessee Press (originally published by the Tennessee Historical Society, 1998)|access-date=May 11, 2018|date=December 25, 2009}}</ref> near the Bellwood community in [[Carthage]]. [[Smith County, Tennessee]].<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/>{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|p=15}} all of his family was involved in music his grandfather was a fiddler and his mother who died when he was about a year old played guitar, whilst another brother learned banjo, he suffered from infant paralysis and was taken in by an aunt named Barbara Lou.  He learned to play the [[harmonica]] and mandolin at the age of three<ref name = \"BlackHistory\"/>{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|p=15}} when he contracted [[poliomyletis|polio]].{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|p=15}} Bailey was confined to bed for a year and could only move his head and arms. His style of playing the harmonica evolved, as he imitated the sounds of the natural world around him and of the trains traveling through the countryside.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.pbs.org/deford/biography/early.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170219215558/http://www.pbs.org/deford/biography/early.html |archive-date=February 19, 2017|title= Deford Bailey: Legend Lost (Early Years)|year= 2002|publisher= Nashville Public Television|access-date= November 27, 2020}}</ref> Though Bailey did recover from his bout with polio, there were some long-term consequences. His back remained slightly misshapen and he only grew to be 4 feet, 10 inches. He was so short and slender as a teenager he was mistaken to be an underage child by railroad ticket agents.{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|pp=16, 32, 39}} His foster father Clark Odom was hired as a manager for a farm near Nashville and in 1908 the family made the move from Smith County.{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|pp=22\u201323}} The Odoms and their foster son lived on Nashville and Franklin Tennessee farms Clark Odom managed for several years. In 1918, the family moved to Nashville when Clark Odom got a city job and Bailey started to perform locally there as an amateur.{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|pp=77, 181}}\n\n==Career==\n[[Image:Deford-bailey-thc-marker-tn1.jpg|right|thumb|A [[Tennessee Historical Commission]] marker near Bailey's birthplace in Smith County]]\n\nBailey's first radio appearance was apparently in September 1925<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Beck |first1=Ken |title=The 'Harmonica Wizard' \u2013 Bellwood's DeFord Bailey became a superstar on the mouth harp |url=https://www.wilsonpost.com/community/bellwood-s-deford-bailey-became-a-superstar-on-the-mouth/article_b53f1ca0-2189-11e8-8fa7-4f45a09696c4.html |publisher=The Wilson Post |access-date=April 22, 2019 |date=March 8, 2018 |archive-date=April 22, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190422061327/https://www.wilsonpost.com/community/bellwood-s-deford-bailey-became-a-superstar-on-the-mouth/article_b53f1ca0-2189-11e8-8fa7-4f45a09696c4.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> on Fred Exum's WDAD, a Nashville station that only lasted from 1925 until sometime in 1927.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Wolfe |first1=Charles K. |title=A Good-Natured Riot: The Birth of the Grand Ole Opry |date=2015 |publisher=[[Vanderbilt University Press]] |pages=32\u201333 |isbn=9780826520753 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=snTqCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA32 |quote=\"on about September 13, 1925 Nashville's first radio station took to the air\"...\"apparently WDAD continued to broadcast until 1927\"}}</ref> His first documented appearances, however, were in 1926 according to ''[[The Tennessean|The Nashville Tennessean]]'' including WDAD on January 14<ref>{{cite web |title=Radio By The Clock \u2013 Week's Programs \u2013 WDAD |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/178464527/ |publisher=[[The Tennessean|The Nashville Tennessean]] {{Subscription required |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} |access-date=April 23, 2019 |page=13 |date=January 10, 1926}}</ref> and [[WSM (AM)|WSM]] on June 19.{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|p=47}} On December 10, 1927, he debuted his trademark song, \"Pan American Blues\" (named for the [[Louisville and Nashville Railroad]]'s ''[[Pan-American (train)|Pan-American]]''), on a program then known as the ''WSM Barn Dance''. At that time ''Barn Dance'' aired after NBC's classical music show, the ''Music Appreciation Hour''. While introducing Bailey, WSM station manager and announcer [[George D. Hay]] exclaimed on-air, \u201cFor the past hour, we have been listening to music largely from Grand Opera, but from now on, we will present \u2018The Grand Ole Opry.\u2019\u201d<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/> \"Pan American Blues\" was the first recording of a harmonica blues solo.<ref name=\"Russell\">{{cite book|first=Tony|last=Russell|year=1997|title=The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray|publisher=Carlton Books|location=Dubai|page=12|isbn=1-85868-255-X}}</ref>\n\nSeveral records by Bailey were issued in 1927 and 1928, all of them harmonica solos. In 1927 he recorded for Brunswick Records in New York City,<ref name = \"Tosches\">{{cite book|last=Tosches|first=Nick|title=Country: The Twisted Roots of Rock 'n' Roll|year=1996|publisher=Da Capo Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VpeGEPCKsesC&pg=PA213|page=213|isbn=9780786750986}}</ref><ref name = \"Oliver\">{{cite book|last=Oliver|first=Paul|title=Barrelhouse Blues: Location Recording and the Early Traditions of the Blues|year=2009|publisher=Basic Books|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZzhGr0rIgAC&pg=PA97|access-date=November 10, 2011|page=97|isbn=9780465019892}}</ref> In 1928 he made the first recordings in Nashville,<ref name=Tennessean/> eight sides<ref name = \"JET\">{{cite journal|title=Grand Ole Opry Legend DeFord Bailey, 82, Dead|journal=JET|date=August 2, 1982|volume=62|issue=21|pages=53|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DLgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53|access-date=November 10, 2011}}</ref> for [[Victor Recording Company|RCA Victor]],<ref name = \"Tosches\"/><ref name = \"Oliver\"/> three of which were issued on the Victor, Bluebird, and RCA labels. Emblematic of the ambiguity of Bailey's position as a recording artist is the fact that his arguably greatest recording, \"[[John Henry (folklore)#Song|John Henry]]{{Broken anchor|date=2024-09-12|bot=User:Cewbot/log/20201008/configuration|target_link=John Henry (folklore)#Song|reason= The anchor (Song) [[Special:Diff/447916989|has been deleted]].}}\", was released by RCA separately in both its \"race\" series and its \"hillbilly\" series.{{sfn|Morton|Wolfe|1993|p=58}} In addition to his well-known harmonica, Bailey also played the guitar, [[Bones (instrument)|bones]], and banjo.<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/><ref name = \"Samples\"/>\n\nBailey was a pioneer member of the WSM ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]'' and one of its most popular performers, appearing on the program from 1927 to 1941.<ref name=\"thealabamaband.com\">{{citation|url= http://www.thealabamaband.com/HallOfFame.html|title= CMA Press Release 2005 Hall of Fame|date= August 29, 2005|access-date= January 25, 2024|archive-date= November 28, 2010|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101128161342/http://thealabamaband.com/HallOfFame.html|url-status= dead}}</ref> During this period he toured with major country stars, including [[Uncle Dave Macon]], [[Bill Monroe]], and [[Roy Acuff]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Morris|first=Edward|title=DeFord Bailey Documentary to Air May 7|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1453654/deford-bailey-documentary-to-air-may-7.jhtml|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120729112318/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1453654/deford-bailey-documentary-to-air-may-7.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 29, 2012|publisher=CMT.Com|access-date=November 10, 2011|date=May 1, 2002}}</ref> Like other Black stars of his day traveling in the [[Southern United States]] and [[Western United States]], he faced difficulties in finding food and accommodations because of discriminatory [[Jim Crow laws]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Oermann|first=Robert K.|title=Behind the Grand Ole Opry Curtain: Tales of Romance and Tragedy|year=2008|publisher=Hachette Digital|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4UkNI_M-H0cC&pg=PT228|access-date=November 10, 2011|chapter=The Harmonica Wizard (Chapter 30)|isbn=9781599951843}}</ref>\n\nBailey was fired by WSM in 1941 because of a licensing conflict between [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] and [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers|ASCAP]], which prevented him from playing his best-known tunes on the radio.<ref>{{cite book|author=David C. Morton|title=Deford Bailey: A Black Star in Early Country Music|year=1993|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=121\u2013130|author2=Charles K. Wolfe|chapter=Chapter 10, They Turned Me Loose to Root Hog or Die}}</ref>  When he was let go from the Opry, that effectively ended his performance and recording career. Bailey then spent the rest of his life running his own shoeshine stand and renting out rooms in his home to make a living.<ref name=Tennessean/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Ghianni |first1=Tim |title=Deford Bailey's legacy shines on in grandson |url=https://www.tnledger.com/editorial/Article.aspx?id=105384 |website=Tennessee Ledger |publisher=[[Nashville Ledger]], Daily News Publishing company |access-date=November 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180329225600/https://www.tnledger.com/editorial/Article.aspx?id=105384 |archive-date=March 29, 2018 |date=March 30, 2018}}</ref> Though he continued to play the harmonica, he rarely performed publicly.<ref name=Tennessean/> One of his rare performances occurred in 1974, when he agreed to appear on the Opry. This was a special event to mark the Opry leaving the [[Ryman Auditorium]] for the [[Grand Ole Opry#Grand Ole Opry House|Grand Ole Opry House]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Harry Horenstein |title=DeFord Bailey (photo) |url=https://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_1213027 |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |access-date=December 18, 2019}}</ref><ref name=Tennessean>{{cite web |author1=Walter Carter  |author2=Randy Hilman |title=DeFord Bailey, Grand Ole Opry's first musician and first artist to record in Nashville, dies at 82: From the archives |website=[[The Tennessean]] |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/country-mile/2019/09/12/deford-bailey-country-musician-broke-barriers-african-american-artists/2264613001/ |access-date=December 18, 2019 |date=July 3, 1982}}</ref> This performance became the impetus for the Opry's annual Old Timers' Shows.<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/>\n\nAfterwards, Bailey continued to perform at the Opry only occasionally. He played there on his 75th birthday in December 1974, at the Old Timers Shows,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Staff captions & photos |title=Nashville Then: Grand Ole Opry's Old Timers' Night March 1975 |url=https://www.tennessean.com/picture-gallery/news/local/2015/03/07/nashville-then-grand-ole-oprys-old-timers-night-march-1975/24561667/ |publisher=[[The Tennessean]] |access-date=November 30, 2020 |date=March 16, 2015}}</ref> and also in April 1982. A few months later that year, in June, he was taken to Nashville's Baptist Hospital in failing health. Bailey died from kidney and heart failure on July 2, 1982, at his daughter's home in Nashville,<ref name=Tennessean/><ref name = \"JET\"/><ref>{{cite web|title=DeFord Bailey (Timeline)|url=https://www.pbs.org/deford/timeline/index.html|publisher=PBS|access-date=November 10, 2011}}</ref> and is buried in [[Greenwood Cemetery (Nashville, Tennessee)|Greenwood Cemetery]] there.<ref name=\"Wolfe\"/>\n\n==Influence and posthumous accolades==\nBailey himself said that he came from a tradition of \"black hillbilly music\".<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/> His family members had played a variety of instruments, including a grandfather who had been a well-known local fiddler in Smith County, Tennessee. He said later when referring to playing the harmonica when he was growing up \"Oh, I wore it out trying to imitate everything I hear! Hens, foxes, hounds, turkeys, and all those trains and things on the road. Everything around me.\"\n\n<ref>{{cite web |last1=Curtiss |first1=Lou |title=DeFord Bailey: The Harmonica Wizard |url=https://sandiegotroubadour.com/deford-bailey-the-harmonica-wizard/ |website=San Diego Troubadour |access-date=January 25, 2024 |date=June 2017 }}</ref> Along with performing well-known genre classics such as \"Cow-Cow Blues\", Bailey also wrote his own signature Opry songs, like the train-imitating \"Pan American Blues\" and the \"Dixie Flyer Blues\".<ref name=Tennessean/> When WSM's power increased to 50,000 watts, Bailey's influence also increased, with harmonica enthusiasts listening to his performances and studying his recordings.<ref name = \"Country Music Hall of Fame\"/>\n\n2005 Nashville Public Television produced the documentary ''DeFord Bailey: A Legend Lost''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/deford/|title=DeFord Bailey: A Legend Lost|publisher=PBS|access-date=June 4, 2011}}</ref> The documentary was broadcast nationally through PBS. Bailey was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] on November 15, 2005. The DeFord Bailey Tribute Garden at the [[George Washington Carver]] Food Park in Nashville was dedicated on June 27, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.earthmattersnetworks.com/#/deford-bailey-garden/4518191398|title= DeFord Bailey honored with Tribute Garden|publisher= Earth Matters|date= June 15, 2007|access-date= August 23, 2010}}</ref> The ''Encyclopedia of Country Music'' called him \"the most significant black country star before World War II.\"<ref>{{cite book|last=Rumble|first=John|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music: The Ultimate Guide to the Music|chapter=Black Artists in Country Music|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=untabCgOVkgC&pg=PA37|editor=Paul Kingsbury|access-date=November 10, 2011|page=37|isbn=9780199770557}}</ref> Bailey is still being referred to as a \"harmonica wizard\" more than three decades after his death.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Beck |first1=Ken |title='Harmonica Wizard' Deford Bailey |url=https://www.carthagecourier.com/2018/03/06/harmonica-wizard-deford-bailey/ |publisher=Carthage Courier |access-date=October 23, 2020 |date=March 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name=\"story\">{{cite web |last1=Lara |first1=Amie |title=DeFord Bailey was 'Harmonica Wizard' |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2014/02/13/deford-bailey-was-harmonica-wizard/5445889/ |publisher=[[The Tennessean]] |access-date=October 23, 2020 |date=February 13, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===78 rpm singles===\n''Listing sourced from the University of Santa Barbara Library/American Discography Project's Discography of American Historical Recordings''<ref>{{cite web |title=DeFord Bailey |url=https://adp.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/mastertalent/detail/106276/Bailey_DeFord |website=Discography of American Historical Recordings |publisher=[[University of California, Santa Barbara Library]] |access-date=August 5, 2020}}</ref>\n* \"Evening Prayer Blues\" / \"Alcoholic Blues\" (Brunswick, 1927)\n* \"Muscle Shoal Blues\" / \"Up Country Blues\" (Brunswick, 1927)\n* \"Dixie Flyer Blues\" / \"Pan American Blues\" (Brunswick, 1927)\n* \"Fox Chase\" / \"Old Hen Cackle\" (Vocalion, 1928)\n* \"Ice Water Blues\" / \"Davidson County Blues\" (Victor, 1929)\n* \"John Henry\" / \"Like I Want To Be\" (split single with [[Noah Lewis (musician)|Noah Lewis Jug Band]]) (Victor 23336, 1932)\n* \"John Henry\" / \"Chester Blues\" (split single with D. H. Bilbro) (Victor 23831, 1933)\n\n===Albums===\n* ''The Legendary DeFord Bailey'' (Tennessee Folklore Society, 1998) (recorded 1974\u20131976)<ref>{{cite web |title=DeFord Bailey |url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/903252-DeFord-Bailey |work=[[Discogs]] |access-date=August 5, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n===Sources===\n* {{cite book |last1=Morton |first1=David C. |last2=Wolfe |first2=Charles K. |year=1993 |title=Deford Bailey: A Black Star in Early Country Music |publisher=University of Tennessee Press |isbn=0-87049-792-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M0TaNRD87bgC&pg=PA15}}\n\n==External links==\n* [https://web.archive.org/web/20060615044646/http://www.defordbailey.info/ Bailey's biographer's site, with audio and photos]\n* [https://www.allmusic.com/artist/deford-bailey-mn0000237296/songs Samples of DeFord Bailey's recordings]\n* [https://www.pbs.org/video/deford-bailey-a-legend-lost-npt-wh7wz7/ The PBS documentary]\n* [http://www.wirz.de/music/baileyde.htm Illustrated DeFord Bailey discography]\n* [https://narratively.com/the-unsung-black-musician-who-changed-country-music/ The Unsung Black Musician Who Changed Country Music], ''Narratively'', January 23, 2020\n* [https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&pg=PA24 The Encyclopedia of Country Music \u2013 ''Deford Bailey'' Chapter, Pages 24\u201325 (David C. Morton)]\n* {{discogs artist|DeFord Bailey}}\n* {{imdb name|3462435}}\n\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n{{2000s Country Music Hall of Fame}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Bailey, Deford}}\n[[Category:1899 births]]\n[[Category:1982 deaths]]\n[[Category:African-American guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country harmonica players]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American banjoists]]\n[[Category:Grand Ole Opry members]]\n[[Category:Country Music Hall of Fame inductees]]\n[[Category:Members of the Country Music Association]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:People from Smith County, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:African-American country musicians]]\n[[Category:20th-century African-American male singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:African-American songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jimmie_Rodgers_(country_singer)","to":"Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)"}],"pages":{"48112":{"pageid":48112,"ns":0,"title":"Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[Jimmie Rodgers]]\n\n{{rcat shell|\n{{R from unnecessary dab}}\n}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mike_Henderson","to":"Mike Henderson"}],"pages":{"41924999":{"pageid":41924999,"ns":0,"title":"Mike Henderson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1953\u20132023)}}\n{{for|the American politician|Mike Henderson (politician)}}\n{{Lead too short|date=December 2021}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Mike Henderson\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Michael James Henderson\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1953|7|14}}\n| birth_place     = [[Independence, Missouri]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and given age|2023|9|22|70}}\n| death_place     = \n| instrument      = Guitar, [[mandolin]], [[fiddle]], harmonica\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[blues]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1981\u20132023\n| label           = [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]], [[Dead Reckoning Records|Dead Reckoning]]\n| past_member_of = [[The SteelDrivers]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.mikehenderson.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Michael James Henderson''' (July 14, 1953 \u2013 September 22, 2023)<ref name=\"BGTobi\">{{cite web |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/mike-henderson-passes/|first=Richard|last=Thompson|title=Mike Henderson passes |date=September 29, 2023|accessdate=September 30, 2023|website=Bluegrass Today}}</ref><ref name=\"KCSobi\">{{cite web |url=https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/kansascity/name/michael-henderson-obituary?id=53184107|title=Michael Henderson Obituary|date=September 26, 2023|accessdate=September 30, 2023|publisher=The Kansas City Star}}</ref> was an American singer-songwriter. In addition to his solo career, which included five studio albums, Henderson was a member of the country band [[The SteelDrivers]] from 2005 to 2011 and was a songwriting collaborator of his former SteelDrivers bandmate [[Chris Stapleton]].\n\n==Biography==\n\n===Early life and career===\nHenderson was born in [[Independence, Missouri]], in 1953.<ref name=\"Gray\">{{cite encyclopedia |last=Gray |first=Michael |author-link=Michael Gray (author) |editor-first=Paul |editor-last=Kingsbury |encyclopedia=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |title=Mike Henderson |year=1998 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-977055-7 |oclc=707922721 |pages=236\n}}</ref><ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|page=186|year=2008|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> He was an original member of [[blues]] group the Bel Airs when they formed in [[Missouri]] in 1981.<ref name=\"belairs\">{{cite web|title=The Bel Airs Bio|url=http://www.belairs.com/bio.html|work=The Bel Airs|access-date=February 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401190848/http://www.belairs.com/bio.html|archive-date=April 1, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Himes|first=Geoffrey|title=MIKE HENDERSON & THE BLUEBLOODS \"Thicker Than Water\" Dead Reckoning|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-570184.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140611061743/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-570184.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 11, 2014|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 5, 1999}}</ref> They released an album, ''Need Me a Car'', on [[Blind Pig Records]] in 1984.<ref name=\"belairs\" /><ref name=\"houston\">{{cite news|last=Sherman|first=Jim|title=Aw, Twern't Nuthin'|url=http://www.houstonpress.com/1997-01-16/music/aw-twern-t-nuthin/full/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Houston Press]]|date=January 16, 1997}}</ref> Henderson left the band in 1985 and moved to [[Nashville]].<ref name=\"belairs\" /><ref name=\"bio\">{{cite web|title=Mike Henderson Bio|url=http://www.mikehenderson.com/bio.htm|work=Mike Henderson|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> The following year, he joined the [[roots rock]] band The Roosters.<ref name=\"bio\" /> He was also a member of spin-off band The Kingsnakes.<ref name=\"bio\" /> The Kingsnakes began playing weekly at the [[Bluebird Cafe]] in July 1986.<ref name=\"bluebird\">{{cite web|title=About {{!}} The Bluebird Cafe|url=http://www.bluebirdcafe.com/about/|work=[[Bluebird Cafe]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> They shortened their name to The Snakes when they were signed by [[Curb Records]].<ref name=\"bluebird\" /> An album, ''The Snakes'', was released by Curb in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|title=''The Snakes'' \u2013 The Snakes|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000653677|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref>\n\nIn 1988, [[The Fabulous Thunderbirds]] covered \"Powerful Stuff\", a song Henderson had written for The Snakes, for the soundtrack to the film ''[[Cocktail (1988 film)|Cocktail]]''.<ref name=\"bio\" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Galipault|first=Gerry|title=Mike Henderson & The Bluebloods swing the blues|url=http://www.pauseandplay.com/mike-henderson-the-bluebloods-swing-the-blues/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=Pause & Play|date=January 10, 1999}}</ref> Henderson later became a staff songwriter for [[EMI Music Publishing|EMI]].<ref name=\"houston\" /> His songs have been recorded by the [[Dixie Chicks]], [[Trisha Yearwood]], [[Gary Allan]] and [[Patty Loveless]], among others.<ref name=\"tennessean\">{{cite news|last=Cooper|first=Peter|title=Peter Cooper on Music: A mandolin player ZZ Top can love|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2011/11/17/peter-cooper-on-music-a-mandolin-player-zz-top-can-love/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|date=November 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name=\"credits\">{{cite web|title=Mike Henderson {{!}} Credits|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=mn0000486733/credits|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> Henderson also found work in Nashville as a [[slide guitar]]ist.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|last=Skelly|first=Richard|title=Mike Henderson {{!}} Biography|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=mn0000486733|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> He played on albums by [[Emmylou Harris]], [[John Hiatt]], [[Joy Lynn White]] and [[Kelly Willis]].<ref name=\"bio\" /><ref name=\"credits\" />\n\n===''Country Music Made Me Do It''===\nHenderson's demos drew the attention of [[country music]] label [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]].<ref name=\"houston\" /> RCA signed Henderson and released his solo debut album, ''Country Music Made Me Do It'', in March 1994.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Country Music Made Me Do It'' \u2013 Mike Henderson|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000110086|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> Bob Cannon of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the album an A\u2212 grade, writing that Henderson's \"enthusiastic field holler and his guitar's riveting twang give off enough sparks to ignite [the songs].\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Cannon|first=Bob|title=Country Music Made Me Do It Review|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,302122,00.htm|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140212221757/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,302122,00.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 12, 2014|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=May 6, 1994}}</ref> Dan Kening of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the album three and a half stars, saying that \"Henderson downplays his guitar chops on his first solo album in favor of his songwriting and strong vocals and acquits himself admirably.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Kening|first=Dan|title=Mike Henderson Country Music Made Me Do It (RCA)|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1994/05/12/mike-hendersoncountry-music-made-me-do-it/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=May 12, 1994}}</ref> The album also received a favorable review from Peter Cronin of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', who declared that \"Henderson comes to the party with plenty of attitude and a distinctive point of view.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Cronin|first=Peter|title=Album Reviews|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NQgEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22mike%20henderson%22%20%22if%20the%20jukebox%20took%20teardrops%22&pg=RA1-PA68|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=March 26, 1994}}</ref>\n\nThe album's first single, \"Hillbilly Jitters\", peaked at number 69 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart.<ref name=\"whitburn\" /> When subsequent singles \"The Want To\" and \"If the Jukebox Took Teardrops\" failed to chart, Henderson was dropped by the label.<ref name=\"reader\">{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Mike Henderson|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/mike-henderson/Content?oid=890203|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Reader]]|date=April 11, 1996}}</ref> \"If the Jukebox Took Teardrops\" was later a minor chart hit for [[Danni Leigh]] in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=''29 Nights'' \u2013 Danni Leigh|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000042159|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===''Edge of Night''===\nAfter being dropped by RCA, Henderson founded the label [[Dead Reckoning Records]] with [[Kieran Kane]], [[Kevin Welch]], [[Tammy Rogers]] and [[Harry Stinson (musician)|Harry Stinson]].<ref name=\"reader\" /> His second album, ''Edge of Night'', was released by Dead Reckoning in January 1996.<ref name=\"houston\" /><ref>{{cite web|title=''Edge of Night'' \u2013 Mike Henderson|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000183441|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> The video for the first single, a cover of [[Eddy Clearwater]]'s \"I Wouldn't Lay My Guitar Down\", was added by [[Country Music Television|CMT]] in February 1996.<ref>{{cite news|title=Billboard Video Monitor|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Og8EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22mike%20henderson%22%20%22lay%20my%20guitar%20down%22&pg=PA76|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=March 2, 1996}}</ref> Tony Scherman of ''Entertainment Weekly'' gave the album a B+ grade, writing that Henderson is \"a good songwriter, even if he wears his influences a little too plainly.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Scherman|first=Tony|title=Edge of Night Review|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,291012,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203141202/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,291012,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 3, 2008|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=January 19, 1996}}</ref> Parry Gettelman of the ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' gave the album five stars, stating that Henderson's \"strong, slightly sandpapery voice is as soulful as it is twangy.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Gettelman|first=Parry|title=Mike Henderson|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/1996/01/26/mike-henderson/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 26, 1996}}</ref> Chet Flippo of ''Billboard'' also reviewed the album favorably, saying that \"Henderson manages to sound at once world-weary and exuberant in a solid lineup of original material and country chestnuts.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Flippo|first=Chet|title=Reviews & Previews|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7g4EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22mike%20henderson%22%20%22edge%20of%20night%22&pg=PA105|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=January 27, 1996}}</ref>\n\n===''First Blood''===\nLater in 1996, Henderson formed the blues band Mike Henderson & the Bluebloods with [[Reese Wynans]] on piano, [[Glenn Worf]] on [[bass (instrument)|bass]] and John Gardner on drums.<ref name=\"houston\" /><ref name=\"allmusic\" /> They released the album ''First Blood'' in October 1996 on Dead Reckoning.<ref>{{cite web|title=''First Blood'' \u2013 Mike Henderson & The Bluebloods|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000613452|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Mike Henderson & the Bluebloods|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/mike-henderson--the-bluebloods/Content?oid=892419|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Reader]]|date=January 9, 1997}}</ref> [[Mark Knopfler]] wrote the album's [[liner notes]].<ref name=\"nodepression\">{{cite news|last=Ray|first=Linda|title=Mike Henderson & The Bluebloods \u2013 First Blood|url=http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/03/mike-henderson-the-bluebloods-first-blood/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|date=March 1997|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222013118/http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/03/mike-henderson-the-bluebloods-first-blood/|archive-date=February 22, 2014}}</ref> [[Alanna Nash]] of ''Entertainment Weekly'' gave the album an A grade, writing that \"''First Blood'''s blistering, seamless blues covers prove [Henderson]'s a remarkable guitarist and frontman.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Nash|first=Alanna|title=First Blood Review|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,294614,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425114608/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,294614,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 25, 2009|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=October 18, 1996}}</ref> A review in ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' stated that \"when the combination of piano, bass, drums and electric guitar is as neck-snappingly strong as it is on the Bluebloods' first album, you don't need other instruments, original compositions or even many original ideas to deliver a knockout blow.\"<ref>{{cite news|title=Picks and Pans Review: First Blood|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20142941,00.html|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=December 9, 1996}}</ref> Linda Ray of ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'' also gave the album a positive review, praising Henderson's \"masterful guitar and vocals\" and saying that \"the way he plays that slide is likely illegal in several states.\"<ref name=\"nodepression\" /> The song \"Pay Bo Diddley\" received some radio airplay.<ref name=\"allmusic\" />\n\n===''Thicker Than Water''===\nMike Henderson & the Bluebloods released their second album, ''Thicker Than Water'', in January 1999 with [[John Barlow Jarvis]] replacing Reese Wynans on piano.<ref name=\"thicker\">{{cite web|last=Byrkit|first=Becky|title=''Thicker Than Water'' \u2013 Mike Henderson & The Bluebloods|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000046781|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> Becky Byrkit of [[AllMusic]] gave the album four stars out of five, writing that \"Henderson contributes a particularly clear vocal style with plenty of simultaneous character from both the blues and true-blue country music.\"<ref name=\"thicker\" /> The album received a mixed review in ''People'', which praised Jarvis' \"richly layered, hard-driving solos\" but compared Henderson's vocals to \"the white-guy-trying-to-sound-soulful desperation of [[Dan Aykroyd]] and [[John Belushi]] in their [[The Blues Brothers|Blues Brothers]] mode.\"<ref>{{cite news|title=Picks and Pans Review: Thicker Than Water|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20127411,00.html|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=January 25, 1999}}</ref> Ed Kopp of ''[[All About Jazz]]'' gave the album a positive review, saying that \"leader Mike Henderson is a highly capable slide guitarist, harpist, and singer, but the guy who makes this CD extra special is John Jarvis.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Kopp|first=Ed|title=Mike Henderson and the Bluebloods: Thicker Than Water|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=4098|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[All About Jazz]]|date=August 1, 1999}}</ref> Tim Steil of the ''Chicago Tribune'' also gave the album a favorable review, stating that \"whether playing [[Hound Dog Taylor]]-ish slide, or blowing harp lines that would make [[Little Walter]] smile, Henderson deftly conjures the sound of '50s Chicago.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Steil|first=Tom|title=Mike Henderson and the Bluebloods Thicker Than Water|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1999/01/17/mike-henderson-and-the-bluebloodsthicker-than-water/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=January 17, 1999}}</ref>\n\n===Later career===\nHenderson toured with Mark Knopfler on his 2001 [[Sailing to Philadelphia Tour]].<ref name=\"bio\" /><ref name=\"tennessean\" /> In 2008, Henderson was one of the founding members of [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] group [[The SteelDrivers]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Lupton|first=John|title=The SteelDrivers put blue in bluegrass|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=1044|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[Country Standard Time]]|date=January 2008}}</ref> He played [[mandolin]], [[Resonator guitar|resophonic guitar]] and harmonica and co-wrote most of the band's original songs.<ref>{{cite web|last=poet|first=j.|title=''Reckless'' \u2013 SteelDrivers|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0002021612|pure_url=yes}}|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> The SteelDrivers' 2010 album ''Reckless'' was nominated for a [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]] at the [[53rd Annual Grammy Awards]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Five artists under the radar at the Grammys|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/awards/grammys/2011-02-07-fiveradar07_ST_N.htm|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=February 7, 2011}}</ref> Henderson left The SteelDrivers in December 2011.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lawless|first=John|title=Mike Henderson moves on|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/mike-henderson-moves-on/|access-date=February 11, 2014|newspaper=Bluegrass Today|date=December 21, 2011}}</ref>\n\n[[Adele]] performed Henderson's song \"If It Hadn't Been for Love\" for her 2011 DVD ''[[Live at the Royal Albert Hall (Adele video)|Live at the Royal Albert Hall]]''.<ref name=\"tennessean\" />\n\nHenderson continued to play weekly shows at the Bluebird Cafe with the Mike Henderson Band.<ref name=\"bluebird\" /><ref name=\"tennessean\" />\n\n===Death===\nMike Henderson died unexpectedly in his sleep on September 22, 2023, at the age of 70.<ref name=\"BGTobi\"/><ref name=\"KCSobi\"/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Hudak |first1=Joseph |title=Mike Henderson, Chris Stapleton Co-Writer and the SteelDrivers Founder, Dead at 70 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/mike-henderson-steeldrivers-dead-obit-1234830058/ |website=Rolling Stone |access-date=23 September 2023 |date=22 September 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Year\n|Mike Henderson, Chris Stapleton \u2013 \"Starting Over\"\n|{{Won}}\n|{{center|<ref>{{Cite web |title=CMA Awards Past Winners & Nominees |url=https://cmaawards.com/past-winners-and-nominees/ |access-date=2023-09-23 |website=CMA Awards |language=en-US}}</ref>}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official website|http://www.mikehenderson.com/}}\n* {{discogs artist|Mike Henderson}}\n* {{IMDb name|3061062}}\n\n{{CMA for Song of the Year}}\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Henderson, Mike}}\n[[Category:1954 births]]\n[[Category:2023 deaths]]\n[[Category:American blues singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Missouri]]\n[[Category:People from Independence, Missouri]]\n[[Category:RCA Records Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Missouri]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Gary_Nicholson_(singer)","to":"Gary Nicholson (singer)"}],"pages":{"39715588":{"pageid":39715588,"ns":0,"title":"Gary Nicholson (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Gary Nicholson\n| image               = \n| image_size          = \n| landscape           = \n| alt                 = \n| caption             = \n| birth_name          = \n| birth_place         = [[Commerce, Texas]], U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/gnicholson |title=Gary Nicholson &#124; The Sky Is Not The Limit &#124; CD Baby Music Store |publisher=Cdbaby.com |access-date=June 19, 2013}}</ref>\n| origin              = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]<br/>[[Blues]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter<br />record producer\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| years_active        = 1970s\u2013present\n}}\n\n'''Gary Nicholson''' is an American singer-songwriter<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.taxi.com/music-business-faq/ar/nicholson.html |title=TAXI A&R Interview: Gary Nicholson, Songwriting Producer<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=January 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105223043/http://www.taxi.com/music-business-faq/ar/nicholson.html |archive-date=January 5, 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and record producer, known mainly for his work in [[country music]] and [[blues]]. He is a two-time Grammy winning producer and was inducted into the Texas Heritage Songwriter's Association Hall of Fame.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards|title=Awards Nominations & Winners|date=April 30, 2017|website=Grammy.com|access-date=May 9, 2021}}</ref> Nicholson has more than 500 recordings and is best known for his work with [[Willie Nelson]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[George Strait]], [[Ringo Starr]], [[B. B. King]], [[Fleetwood Mac]] and [[Billy Joe Shaver]].<ref name=AllMusic>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gary-nicholson-mn0000153133 | title=Gary Nicholson | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=November 21, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Early life and education==\nNicholson was born in Commerce, Texas. He grew up in Garland, Texas and began playing guitar in his teenage years in bands such as \"The Valiants\", \"The Catalinas\" and \"The Untouchables\". Afterward, Nicholson attended [[University of North Texas]], majoring in music.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/lifestyles/arts/columnists/mario-tarradell/20110629-spotlight-on-texas-artists-gary-nicholson-greezy-wheels-and-bigelow-station-.ece | title=Spotlight on Texas Artists: Gary Nicholson, Greezy Wheels and Bigelow Station | publisher=The Dallas Morning News | date=June 29, 2011 | access-date=November 21, 2015 | author=Tarradell, Mario}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===Early career===\nIn 1970, Nicholson and his band drove to Los Angeles, California. The band won a talent contest at the Palomino Club and met musicians [[James Burton]], [[Red Rhodes]] and [[Clarence White]]. Afterwards, he formed the bluegrass/folk trio, \"The Whitehorse Brothers\", playing in Southern California. The group expanded and became \"Uncle Jim's Music\" and was signed to MCA/Kapp records for two albums.<ref name=bio>{{cite web | url=http://www.garynicholson.com/bio/ | title=Bio | publisher=Gary Nicholson | access-date=November 21, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 1973, Nicholson moved back to Texas and started the rock/country band \"Hot Sauce\". During this time, he first played with [[Delbert McClinton]]. His friend and bandmate, Jim Ed Norman, recorded Nicholson's song \"Jukebox Argument\", sung by [[Mickey Gilley]] in the film ''[[Urban Cowboy]]''.<ref name=bio/>\n\nIn 1980, Nicholson signed with Norman's Jensong Music and moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gomemphis.com/news/2011/aug/25/nicholson-enjoys-best-of-both-worlds/ |title=Songwriter Gary Nicholson enjoys best of both worlds \u00bb GoMemphis.com |access-date=April 1, 2014 |archive-date=September 14, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914055823/http://www.gomemphis.com/news/2011/aug/25/nicholson-enjoys-best-of-both-worlds/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> He played lead guitar for [[Guy Clark]] during the recording of the album ''Better Days''. [[Mickey Gilley]] recorded Nicholson's songs \"[[Your Love Shines Through]]\" and \"Ladies Night\". During this time, he also played guitar for such artists as [[Billy Joe Shaver]], [[Bobby Bare]] and [[Guy Clark]].<ref name=AllMusic/>\n\nIn 1983, Nicholson signed a publishing contract with Tree Publishing (now [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]]).<ref>{{cite web |author=Interviewed by Michael Laskow |url=http://www.taxi.com/music-business-faq/ar/nicholson.html |title=TAXI A&R Interview: Gary Nicholson, Songwriting Producer |publisher=Taxi.com |access-date=June 19, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105223043/http://www.taxi.com/music-business-faq/ar/nicholson.html |archive-date=January 5, 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Gary Nicholson |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/gary-nicholson-mn0000153133 |title=Gary Nicholson \u2013 Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=June 19, 2013}}</ref> He achieved his first number 1 hit in 1984 with the song \"[[That's the Thing About Love]]\", recorded by [[Don Williams]] and \"[[The Power of Love (Charley Pride song)|The Power of Love]]\", recorded by [[Charley Pride]]. In 1986, he wrote six songs for [[T. Graham Brown]]'s debut album and in 1987 the title and five others on his second release, ''Brilliant Conversationalist''.<ref name=nashville/>\n\nHe penned a number 1 hit in 1993 with \"[[One More Last Chance]]\" recorded and co-written by [[Vince Gill]]. In 1995, Nicholson co-wrote six songs with [[John Prine]] for his album, ''[[Lost Dogs and Mixed Blessings]]''. He co-wrote a song for [[Waylon Jennings]] called \"[[Working Without a Net]]\" in 1996. He received ASCAP Awards in 1997 for the songs, \"[[Givin' Water to a Drowning Man]]\", by [[Lee Roy Parnell]], and \"[[A Thousand Times a Day]]\", by [[Patty Loveless]]. Nicholson also left Sony/ATV Music Publishing to start his own publishing company, Gary Nicholson Music ASCAP, during this time. In 1998, Nicholson wrote the album title and single \"[[The Trouble with the Truth (song)|Trouble with the Truth]]\" by [[Patty Loveless]]. In 1999, his song \"[[Live, Laugh, Love (song)|Live, Laugh, Love]]\" was the album title and single for [[Clay Walker]].<ref name=AllMusic/><ref name=bio/>\n\n===Later career===\nIn 2001, his song \"[[She Couldn't Change Me]]\" by [[Montgomery Gentry]] reached number two on Billboard Hot Country Songs. In 2002, Nicholson's song \"[[Squeeze Me In]]\" became a hit duet for [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Trisha Yearwood]]. He also charted for the singles, \"When Love Gets Ahold of You\" by [[Reba McEntire]], \"[[Back in Your Arms Again]]\" by [[The Mavericks]] and \"The Reason Why\" by [[Vince Gill]].<ref name=nashville>{{cite web | url=https://www.nashvillesongwriters.com/gary-nicholson | title=Gary Nicholson | date=November 29, 2014 | publisher=Nashville Songwriters Association International | access-date=November 21, 2015}}</ref> In 2003, he co-wrote the single \"Never Without You\" with [[Ringo Starr]] and has collaborated on each of his last five records.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6422342/ringo-starr-announces-new-album-tour-for-spring-2015 | title=Ringo Starr Announces New Album, Tour for Spring 2015 | magazine=Billboard | date=December 29, 2014 | access-date=November 21, 2015 | author=Stutz, Colin}}</ref> In 2008, Nicholson co-wrote the title song, \"[[Skin Deep (Buddy Guy album)|Skin Deep]]\", for Buddy Guy, which was number one on the Billboard Blues Chart and Grammy nominated. He co-wrote \"The Git Go\" with [[Billy Joe Shaver]] for [[Willie Nelson]]'s ''[[Band of Brothers (Willie Nelson album)|Band of Brothers]]'' album, and co-wrote \"It Ain't You\" with [[Waylon Jennings]], as a Ray Benson/Willie Nelson duet.<ref name=AllMusic/>\n\nNicholson has more than 500 recordings of his songs during his career.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite web|url=http://nosurfmusic.com/thenosurfreview/reviews/garynicholson-texassongbook/index.html|title=The No Surf Review: Gary Nicholson \u2013 Texas Songbook|website=Nosurfmusic.com|access-date=May 9, 2021}}</ref> He has co-written songs with many notable songwriters and artists including [[Ringo Starr]], [[Stevie Nicks]], [[Neil Diamond]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Los Lonely Boys]], [[Jimmy Webb]], [[Michael McDonald (musician)|Michael McDonald]], [[Brad Paisley]], among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gomemphis.com/news/2011/aug/25/nicholson-enjoys-best-of-both-worlds/ |title=Songwriter Gary Nicholson enjoys best of both worlds |publisher=GoMemphis.com |date=August 25, 2011 |access-date=June 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Leggett |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/seth-walker-mn0000732799/biography |title=Seth Walker &#124; Biography |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=March 22, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===Production===\nDuring his career, Nicholson has produced five projects for [[Delbert McClinton]], winning Grammys in the Best Contemporary Blues category for the albums \"Nothing Personal\" in 2001<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1441346/delbert-mcclintons-nothing-personal-actually-is/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127111142/http://www.mtv.com/news/1441346/delbert-mcclintons-nothing-personal-actually-is/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=November 27, 2015 | title=Delbert McClinton's Nothing Personal Actually Is | publisher=MTV | date=March 6, 2001 | access-date=November 21, 2015 | author=Dexter, Kerry}}</ref> and \"Cost of Living\" in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/delbert-mcclinton-cost-of-living-delbert-mcclinton-new-west-records-review-by-doug-collette.php | title=Delbert McClinton: Delbert McClinton: Cost Of Living (2005) | publisher=All About Jazz | date=October 6, 2005 | access-date=November 21, 2015 | author=Collette, Doug}}</ref> Nicholson has also produced for [[Billy Joe Shaver]], [[The Judds]], [[Wynonna Judd|Wynonna]], [[Pam Tillis]], [[T. Graham Brown]] and Marcia Ball.<ref name=\"johnjarrardfoundation\" />\n\n==Awards and recognition==\nHe was nominated to the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] in 2006 and inducted into Texas Heritage Songwriter's Association Hall of Fame in 2011.  He has received ASCAP Awards for the songs, \"Giving Water to a Drowning Man\" and \"A Thousand Times a Day\".<ref name=\"johnjarrardfoundation\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.johnjarrardfoundation.com/artist/gary-nicholson/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150118174242/https://www.johnjarrardfoundation.com/artist/gary-nicholson/|url-status=dead|title=Gary Nicholson &#124; The John Jarrard Foundation<!-- Bot generated title -->|archivedate=January 18, 2015|access-date=May 9, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn June 30, 1973, Nicholson married Barbara Ellendorff.\nHe is from Garland, Texas and has lived in Nashville, Tennessee since 1980.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/73385053/ | title=Gary Nicholsons live in Van Nuys | work=The Garland Daily News | date=July 17, 1973 | access-date=November 21, 2015 | author=Tolbert, Gary}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!
