Film!!Song!!Artist\n|-\n| ''Urban Cowboy''|| \"Jukebox Argument\"||Mickey Gilley<ref name=yamaha>{{cite web | url=http://www.yamaha.com/artists/garynicholson.html | title=Gary Nicholson \u2013 Biography | publisher=Yamaha Artists | access-date=November 21, 2015}}</ref>\n|-\n| ''Message in a Bottle''|| \"Beyond The Blue\"||Beth Nielsen Chapman<ref name=yamaha/>\n|-\n| ''Happy Texas''||\"Are You Happy Baby\"||Lee Roy Parnell<ref name=yamaha/>\n|-\n| ''Where the Heart Is''||\"Beyond The Blue\"||Emmylou Harris/Patty Griffin<ref name=yamaha/>\n|-\n| ''Crazy Heart''||\"Fallin and Flyin\"||Jeff Bridges<ref>{{cite web | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/02/06/crazy-heart-controversy-over-soundtrack-credit/ | title=\"Crazy Heart\" Controversy Over Soundtrack Credit | work=The Wall Street Journal | department=Speakeasy | date=February 6, 2010 | access-date=November 21, 2015 | author=Kurutz, Steven}}</ref>\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.garynicholson.com/ Official website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Nicholson, Gary}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Garland, Texas]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:University of North Texas College of Music alumni]]\n[[Category:Record producers from Texas]]\n[[Category:Singers from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:American blues singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Commerce, Texas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jasmine_Rae","to":"Jasmine Rae"}],"pages":{"22475595":{"pageid":22475595,"ns":0,"title":"Jasmine Rae","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian singer and songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=July 2017}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jasmine Rae\n| image           = Jasmine Rae APRA 2012 (1).jpg\n| image_size      =\n| caption         = Jasmine Rae in 2012\n| birth_name      =\n| origin          = [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, harmonica, piano\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[blues]], [[Soul music|soul]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2008\u2013present\n| label           = [[ABC Music]]\n| associated_acts = [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Alan Jackson]], [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]], [[Miranda Lambert]], [[Catherine Britt]], [[Joe Nichols]], [[Kellie Pickler]], [[Kasey Chambers]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.jasminerae.com/}}\n}}\n\n[[File:Jasmine Rae - Heartbeat (Official Music Video).webm|thumb|Jasmine Rae performing \"Heartbeat\".]]\n\n'''Jasmine Rae''' is an Australian singer and songwriter who has released five studio albums via [[ABC Music]] Australia. Rae has been nominated for four [[ARIA Music Awards]] and has won two [[CMC Music Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jasminerae.com.au/news.cfm |title=Jasmine Rae \u2013 Listen Here: Official Website |accessdate=21 June 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701122234/http://www.jasminerae.com.au/news.cfm |archivedate=1 July 2011  }}</ref> and received the 'Global Artist of the Year' award by the US [[Country Music Association]] in 2013. She is also an eleven-time Golden Guitar nominee.\n\n==Biography==\n===2008\u20132010: Telstra Road to Tamworth and ''Look It Up'' ===\nIn 2008, Rae auditioned for and won the Telstra Road to Tamworth.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.beinvolved.com.au/spo-arts-a-community/country-music/road-to-tamworth-previous-winners |title=Telstra Road to Tamworth - Previous Winners |access-date=6 February 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712060217/http://www.beinvolved.com.au/spo-arts-a-community/country-music/road-to-tamworth-previous-winners |archive-date=12 July 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> Her prize was a recording contract with [[ABC Music]] and a performance at the 2008 CMA music festival in [[Nashville]].\n\nRae recorded and release her debut studio album ''[[Look It Up (album)|Look It Up]]'' in September 2008. The title track, \"[[Look It Up (song)|Look It Up]]\" was later covered by American country artist [[Ashton Shepherd]], which become a Top 20 hit on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart.\n\nIn 2009, Rae toured with [[Brooks & Dunn]].\n\n===2011\u20132012: ''Listen Here'' ===\nIn March 2011, Rae released her second studio album ''[[Listen Here (Jasmine Rae album)|Listen Here]]''. The album debuted at No. 1 on the ARIA Australian Artists Country Chart and No. 35 on the ARIA Albums Chart. Two singles \"Hunky Country Boys\" and \"I'll Try Anything\" topped the Australian Country airplay charts.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}} Those songs plus \"I Faked It\" also went to No. 1 on the CMC Music Video chart. The album was nominated for the [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.destinationnsw.com.au/news-and-media/media-releases/2011-aria-awards-nominations-announced|title=2011 ARIA Awards nominations announced {{!}} Destination NSW|website=www.destinationnsw.com.au|language=en-AU|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> Jasmine was also a Golden Guitar nominee for Female Artist of the Year at the Australian Country Music Awards the following January.\n\nIn 2012 Australian Music fans voted Jasmine Rae, CMC OZ Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/pages/main-menu/news/latest-news/the-cmc-awards-winners |title=Country Music News - Latest local and international country music news &#124; Country Music Channel |access-date=10 September 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324161514/http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/pages/main-menu/news/latest-news/the-cmc-awards-winners |archive-date=24 March 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref> She remains the only female solo artist to ever win the award. In November 2012, Rae released a Christmas EP titled ''[[Santa's Little Helper (EP)|Santa's Little Helper]]''.\n\nIn 2013 she received a CMA Award (US) for Global Artist of the Year<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thewest.com.au/entertainment/music/country-starlet-is-boss-of-her-domain-ng-ya-358206|title=Jasmine Rae|date=2 September 2013|work=The West Australian|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>\n\n===2013\u20132014: ''If I Want To'' ===\nIn August 2013, Rae released her third studio album ''[[If I Want To]]''; the title track shot straight to the top of the CMC Top 30 Countdown chart and held strong for four weeks. The track also topped the Australian Country Radio charts. ''[[If I Want To]]'' was nominated for ARIA Award for Best Country Album.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/aria-awards-2013-nominees-revealed-fine-arts-award-winners-announced/#/slide/1|title=ARIA Awards 2013 Nominees Revealed, Fine Arts Award Winners Announced \u2013 Music Feeds|date=1 October 2013|work=Music Feeds|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> and four Golden Guitar Awards at the 2014 CMA Awards; for Album of the Year, Top Selling Album of the Year, Single of the Year and Female Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.northernstar.com.au/news/lee-kernaghan-leads-2014-golden-guitar-nominations/2084025/|title=Lee Kernaghan leads the 2014 Golden Guitar nominations|last=Cronin|first=Seanna|work=Northern Star|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2014, Jasmine Rae won her second CMC Music Award for 'Female Oz Artist of the Year.'<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/morgan-evans-wins-big-at-the-cmc-awards|title=Morgan Evans wins big at the CMC Awards {{!}} Country Music Channel on Foxtel|date=1 March 2014|work=Country Music Channel|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Rae featured on [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]]'s song \"Quit This Time\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2prEUwvmQ70 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211220/2prEUwvmQ70 |archive-date=2021-12-20 |url-status=live|title=Jasmine Rae & Adam Brand \u2013 Quit This Time (Music Video)|last=Jasmine Rae|date=30 September 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> from Brand's album ''[[My Side of the Street]]'' which was released in August 2014.\n\n===2015\u20132019: ''Heartbeat'' ===\nRae released her fourth album, titled ''[[Heartbeat (Jasmine Rae album)|Heartbeat]]'' through ABC Music / Universal Music Australia on 15 May 2015. The single \"Heartbeat\" became her ninth number-one Australian country single<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jasminerae.com/#!heartbeartno1radio/csca|title=JASMINE RAE \u2013 OFFICIAL WEBSITE \u2013 Singer/Songwriter, Actor, Entertainer|website=jasminerae.com}}</ref> and \"When I Found You\": \u2013 a song she originally wrote for her best friends wedding has been viewed more than 10 million times on YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jasmine Rae|title=Jasmine Rae \u2013 When I Found You (Official Music Video)|website=[[YouTube]]|date=1 November 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-T-aSHM0fc |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211220/L-T-aSHM0fc |archive-date=2021-12-20 |url-status=live|access-date=20 August 2018}}{{cbignore}}</ref> \"Everybody Wants to Take My Money\" was a finalist in the 2016 International Songwriting Competition.\n\n''Heartbeat'' was nominated for two Golden Guitar awards in 2016 and Jasmine was again nominated for CMC 'Female Oz Artist of the Year' in 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/2016-cmc-music-awards-finalists-announced|title=2016 CMC Music Awards finalists announced {{!}} Country Music Channel on Foxtel|date=3 March 2016|work=Country Music Channel|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> and 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.workingbull.com.au/news/cmc-music-awards-2017-finalists/|title=CMC Music Awards 2017: Finalists \u2022 Working Bull Pty Ltd|date=1 March 2017|work=Working Bull Pty Ltd|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Like ''[[If I Want To]]'', the album was produced by Luke Wooten.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://themusic.com.au/music/streams/2015/05/12/jasmine-rae-heartbeat/|title=EXCLUSIVE: Jasmine Rae \u2013 Heartbeat|website=theMusic|language=en-GB|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn 2018, Jasmine toured with US country singer [[Granger Smith]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/5626945/why-2018-has-been-a-roller-coaster-ride-for-jasmine-rae/ |title=Jasmine Rae reflects on Granger Smith tour success and When I Found You court battle|newspaper=The Northern Daily Leader |date=4 September 2018}}</ref> and began writing for a new album.\n\nIn 2019, Jasmine released the singles \"Right Now\" and \"Party on the Couch\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/country/jasmine-rae-and-friends-enjoy-a-party-on-the-couch/|title=Jasmine Rae and friends enjoy a 'Party On The Couch' - Tone Country|accessdate=16 May 2023}}</ref>\u2014her first official music video in over two and a half years.\n\nJasmine has also been announced as an artist on the 2020 CMC Rocks QLD line-up.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://themusic.com.au/news/cmc-rocks-qld-2020-line-up/rZO1oaCjoqU/ | title=Miranda Lambert, Kip Moore & Morgan Evans Lead CMC Rocks QLD 2020 Line-up }}</ref>\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Lion Side'' ===\nIn 2020 Jasmine released the new singles \"Green Light\" and \"Don't Do It for the Haters\" plus the album ''Lion Side''. The album was nominated for the ARIA Award for Best Country Album<ref>{{Cite web|title=ARIA Awards 2020 Nominees|url=https://www.aria.com.au/awards/nominees|access-date=2021-02-02|website=www.aria.com.au|language=en}}</ref> and the album peaked at #11 on the ARIA Albums chart, #2 on the AIR Independent Albums chart and #1 on the ARIA Australian Country Albums chart. Jasmine was also nominated for 'Female Artist of the Year' and 'Contemporary Country Album of the Year' at the 2021 Golden Guitar Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title=2021 Golden Guitar Nominees Revealed|url=https://www.kixcountry.com.au/country-confidential/47957-2021-golden-guitar-nominees-revealed-updating|access-date=2021-02-02|website=www.kixcountry.com.au|date=19 November 2020|language=en-gb}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:17em;\"| Details\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"50\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australian-charts.com/search.asp?cat=a&search=Jasmine+Rae|title=australian-charts.com \u2013 Australian charts portal|publisher=australian-charts.com|accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref>\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:17em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Santa's Little Helper (EP)|Santa's Little Helper]]''\n| \n* Release date: 16 November 2012\n* Label: ABC Music (3723217)\n* Formats: CD, download\n|}\n\n==Awards==\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] are a set of annual ceremonies presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987. Rae has been nominated for four [[ARIA Music Awards]], all in the category [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]].<ref name=\"ARIA 2020 Wins\">{{cite web | url = https://www.aria.com.au/awards/news/and-the-2020-aria-award-goes-to | title = And the 2020 ARIA Awards Go To\u2026 | publisher = Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | access-date = 3 December 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201126005048/https://www.aria.com.au/awards/news/and-the-2020-aria-award-goes-to | archive-date = 26 November 2020 | url-status = live }}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2009|2009]] || ''Look it Up'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2011|2011]] || ''Listen Here'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2013|2013]] || ''If I Want to'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[2020 ARIA Music Awards|2020]] || ''Lion Side'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===CMC Music Awards===\nRae has Won two [[CMC Music Awards]] and been a finalist 4 other times.\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Award\n!Result\n|-\n|2012\n|CMC Oz Artist of the Year\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|2014\n|CMC Female Oz Artist of the Year\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|2014\n|CMC Australian Music Video of the Year ('If I Want To')\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|2015\n|CMC Female Oz Artist of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|2016\n|CMC Female Oz Artist of the Year\n|{{nominated}}\n|-\n|2017\n|CMC Australian Female Artist of the Year \n|{{nominated}}\n|}\n\n===CMA Awards (US)===\nThe Jeff Walker Global Country Artist Award recognises outstanding achievements by a country music artist originally signed outside of the United States \u2013 in both furthering the popularity of Country Music and bringing attention to the Country Music format in their foreign-based territory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cmaworld.com/cma-announces-2017-international-awards-recipients/|title=CMA Announces 2017 International Awards Recipients|accessdate=16 May 2023}}</ref>\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Award\n!Result\n|-\n|2013\n|CMA Global Artist of the Year<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cmaworld.com/cma-presents-international-awards-during-australias-cmc-rocks-the-hunter-festival/|title=CMA Presents International Awards During Australia's CMC Rocks The Hunter Festival|accessdate=16 May 2023}}</ref>\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{Jasmine Rae}}\n\n==External links==\n{{commons category|Jasmine Rae}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Rae, Jasmine}}\n[[Category:1987 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:Australian women songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian women singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Pokey_LaFarge","to":"Pokey LaFarge"}],"pages":{"34072056":{"pageid":34072056,"ns":0,"title":"Pokey LaFarge","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Pokey LaFarge\n| image             = Pokey LaFarge 2012 - Reutlingen.JPG\n| caption           = Pokey LaFarge live at Reutlingen, Germany, May 2, 2012\n| origin            = St. Louis, Missouri, U.S.\n| birth_name        = Andrew Heissler\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1983|6|26}}\n| birth_place       = [[Bloomington, Illinois]],  U.S.\n| genre             = {{Hlist|[[Blues]]|[[folk music|folk]]|[[country music|country]]|[[swing music|swing]]|[[jazz]]}}\n| occupation        = Musician, singer-songwriter, actor\n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar, [[mandolin]]\n| years_active      = {{start date|2006}}\u2013present\n| label             = [[Third Man Records|Third Man]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[New West Records]]\n| spouse            = Addie Hamilton (married 2023\u2013present)\n| website           = {{URL|www.pokeylafarge.net/}}\n}}\n\n'''Pokey LaFarge''' (born '''Andrew Heissler''', June 26, 1983){{citation needed|date=March 2021}} is an American musician and singer-songwriter.\n\n== Early life ==\n[[File:Pokey LaFarge Square Room Knoxville TN April 2010.jpg|200px|left|thumb|At the Square Room in Knoxville, Tennessee, April 17, 2010]]\nLaFarge was born Andrew Heissler in [[Bloomington, Illinois|Bloomington]], Illinois.<ref name=\"Craft\">{{cite web|last1=Craft|first1=Dan|title=Twin City Native Pokey LaFarge Digs Our Musical Roots|url=http://www.pantagraph.com/entertainment/go/twin-city-native-pokey-lafarge-digs-our-musical-roots/article_4f5ec9ec-7c45-11e2-ae3d-0019bb2963f4.html|website=Pantagraph|access-date=21 February 2013|date=21 February 2013|quote=Wouldn't you know: Bloomington-Normal spawns a music original like Pokey LaFarge and Wikipedia tells the world that Benton, half a state away, performed the honors. 'Benton?' responds LaFarge in a bemused tone that suggests the popular online information resource should be consulted but never believed. 'No, I was born in Bloomington, at St. Joe's.'}}</ref> The nickname \"Pokey\" was coined by his mother, who would scold him to hurry when he was a child.<ref name=\"thedailypage.com\">{{cite web| last1 = Steinhoff| first1 = Jessica | title=Pokey LaFarge is a Musical Time Traveler|url=http://isthmus.com/music/pokey-lafarge-is-a-musical-time-traveler/|website=Isthmus|access-date=10 July 2011|language=en-us|date=8 December 2011}}</ref>\n\nLaFarge took an interest in history and literature during his childhood, and was greatly influenced by his grandfathers. One was a member of the St. Louis Banjo Club who gave him his first guitar and tenor [[banjo]]. The other, an amateur historian, taught him about the [[American Civil War]] and [[World War II]].<ref name=\"Kasten\">{{cite web|last1=Kasten|first1=Roy|title=Pokey LaFarge Forges His Own Path Through Old-Time Country and Blues|url=https://www.riverfronttimes.com/stlouis/pokey-lafarge-forges-his-own-path-through-old-time-country-and-blues/Content?oid=2500149|website=Riverfront Times|access-date=10 July 2017|date=17 February 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn his early teens, he discovered an appreciation for older blues musicians like [[Skip James]], [[Robert Wilkins]], and [[Sleepy John Estes]]. After hearing [[Bill Monroe]] at age 16, LaFarge traded the guitar his grandfather had given him for a [[mandolin]].<ref name=\"DeYoung\">{{cite web| last1 = DeYoung | first1=Bill | title=Pokey LaFarge & the South City Three|url=https://www.connectsavannah.com/savannah/pokey-lafarge-and-the-south-city-three/Content?oid=2135969|website=Connect Savannah|access-date=10 July 2017|date=15 November 2011}}</ref>\n\nHe adopted the name \"Pokey LaFarge\" because it sounded like what he was looking for musically during the time he was moving around the country.<ref name=\"Craft\"/> After graduating from [[University High School (Normal, Illinois)|University High School]] in 2001,<ref name=\"Craft\"/> at the age of seventeen he hitchhiked to the west coast and earned a living as a busker on streets, sidewalks, and pedestrian malls. He met [[Ryan Koenig]] and Joey Glynn of the St. Louis band The Rum Drum Ramblers while he was playing on a street in [[Asheville, North Carolina|Asheville]], North Carolina. Koenig and Glynn began playing with LaFarge in 2008, and the addition of Adam Hoskins in 2009 resulted in the formation of the South City Three.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unewsonline.com/2011/12/08/straight-from-st-louis-pokey-lafarge-and-the-south-city-three |title=Straight from St. Louis: Pokey LaFarge and the South City Three &#124; The University News |website=Unewsonline.com |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref><ref name=\"Pokey\">{{cite web |url=http://www.pokeylafarge.net/biography/about-pokey-lafarge |title=About Mr. LaFarge |access-date=2011-12-15 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217061424/http://www.pokeylafarge.net/biography/about-pokey-lafarge/ |archive-date=2011-12-17 }}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n[[File:AH 2012.JPG|200px|right|thumb|LaFarge in Reutlingen, Germany, May 2, 2012]]\nLaFarge independently released his first album, ''Marmalade'', in 2006.<ref name=\"Collar\">{{cite web|last1=Collar|first1=Matt|title=Pokey LaFarge|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/pokey-lafarge-mn0002092058/biography|website=AllMusic|access-date=13 August 2017}}</ref> During the same year, he toured with [[The Hackensaw Boys]]. His second solo album, ''Beat, Move & Shake'', was released in 2008 by [[Big Muddy Records]].\n\n''Riverboat Soul'', the first album with The South City Three, was recorded in July 2009 at the Nashville studio of producer Phil Harris using vintage instruments and electronics. It was released in 2010 by [[Free Dirt Records]] and won the Independent Music Award for Best Americana Album.<ref name=\"Pokey\" /> The group's second album, ''Middle of Everywhere'', won the same award in 2011. The band released ''Chittlin' Cookin' Time in Cheatham County'' produced by [[Jack White]] for his label [[Third Man Records]].<ref name=\"Pokey\" /> White asked the band to collaborate with him on the song \"I Guess I Should Go to Sleep\" for his album ''[[Blunderbuss (album)|Blunderbuss]]'', followed by opening for him on tour.<ref name=\"Collar\" />\n\nIn 2013, LaFarge signed with Third Man Records and released his first album on the label, the eponymously titled ''Pokey LaFarge'', accompanied by a larger band that included [[Chloe Feoranzo]], Matthew Meyer, and T.J. Muller. During the next year, he signed with [[Rounder Records]] and released ''Something in the Water'' in April 2015.<ref name=\"Collar\" /><ref name=\"Thomas\">{{cite web|last1=Thomas|first1=Gideon|title=Pokey LaFarge: Something in the Water |url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/193577-pokey-lafarge-something-in-the-water/| website=PopMatters| access-date=10 July 2017| date=8 June 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 2017 his album ''Manic Revelations'' was released on Rounder Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Pokey-LaFarge-Manic-Revelations/master/1178972 |title=Pokey LaFarge \u2013 Manic Revelations &#124; Releases |publisher=Discogs |access-date=2020-05-30}}</ref>\n\nOn January 22, 2020 LaFarge announced the release of a new album called ''Rock Bottom Rhapsody''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pokeylafarge.net |title=Pokey LaFarge |publisher=Pokey LaFarge |access-date=2020-05-30}}</ref> which was released on April 10 on the New West label.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=10930|title=LaFarge announces new album on new label|website=Countrystandardtime.com}}</ref>\n\nLaFarge released his seventh studio album, ''In the Blossom of Their Shade'', on October 15, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |title=In The Blossom of Their Shade, by Pokey LaFarge |url=https://pokeylafarge.bandcamp.com/album/in-the-blossom-of-their-shade |access-date=2022-10-05 |website=Pokey LaFarge |language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn February 13, 2024, LaFarge announced the release of a new album called ''Rhumba Country'' to be released on May 10, 2024, on the New West label.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Pearis |first=Bill |title=Pokey LaFarge heads to 'Rhumba Country' on new album, touring (listen to \"Sister Andre\") |url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/pokey-lafarge-heads-to-rhumba-country-on-new-album-touring-listen-to-sister-andre/ |access-date=2024-03-13 |website=BrooklynVegan.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Appearances==\n*The group was featured by [[NPR]] on the ''Tiny Desk Concert'' series in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bob Boilen |url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/135508843/pokey-lafarge-tiny-desk-concert |title=Pokey LaFarge: Tiny Desk Concert |website=Npr.org  |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>\n*LaFarge wrote a song for the soundtrack of ''Brick By Chance and Fortune'', a documentary directed by friend of the band, [[Bill Streeter]], released in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insidestl.com/insideSTLcom/Community/STLMovies/tabid/258/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/7819/INTERVIEW-Director-Bill-Streeter-of-Brick-by-Chance-and-Fortune-Makes-Brick-Interesting.aspx |title=INTERVIEW: Director Bill Streeter of \"Brick by Chance and Fortune\" Makes Brick Interesting > insideSTL.com > STL Movies \u2013 Reviews, Previews and More |access-date=2012-01-03 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223035708/http://www.insidestl.com/insideSTLcom/Community/STLMovies/tabid/258/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/7819/INTERVIEW-Director-Bill-Streeter-of-Brick-by-Chance-and-Fortune-Makes-Brick-Interesting.aspx |archive-date=2011-12-23 }}</ref>\n* LaFarge and the members of the South City Three played on \"I Guess I Should Go To Sleep\", a track from [[Jack White]]'s album ''[[Blunderbuss (album)|Blunderbuss]]'' released on April 24, 2012.<ref name=\"nashvillemusicguide1\">{{cite web|author=Amanda |url=http://www.nashvillemusicguide.com/pokey-lafarge-and-the-south-city-three/ |title=Pokey LaFarge and the South City Three |date=20 April 2012 |publisher=Nashville Music Guide |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>\n* On September 23, 2012, LaFarge contributed to the soundtrack of [[HBO]]'s ''[[Boardwalk Empire]]'' with his rendition of the pop standard \"Lovesick Blues\". The song was featured in the last scene and end credits of the episode \"Spaghetti & Coffee\"<ref name=\":0\">{{cite web|last=Hyten |first=Ty |url=http://www.listenupdenver.com/15707/pokey-lafarge-talks-jack-white-boardwalk-empire-taylor-swift-and-more/ |title=Pokey LaFarge Talks Jack White, Boardwalk Empire, and More |website=Listenupdenver.com |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>\n* LaFarge collaborated with [[JD McPherson]] on a rendition of country legend Bob Wills' \"Good Old Oklahoma\", released on June 28, 2013. All of the proceeds from the track go to the Oklahoma City Community Fund's Tornado Relief endowment.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Blistein |first=Jon |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jd-mcpherson-and-pokey-lafarge-celebrate-good-old-oklahoma-song-premiere-20130628 |title=JD McPherson and Pokey LaFarge Celebrate 'Good Old Oklahoma' \u2013 Song Premier |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2013-06-28 |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>\n* Pokey & The South City Three recorded Jack White's track \"Red's Theater of The Absurd\" which appeared in ''[[Lone Ranger (2013 film)|The Lone Ranger]]''{{'}}s original score. The film was released on July 3, 2013 and the band made a brief appearance in the film.<ref name=\":0\" /> \n* The band played on episode 136<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.martystuart.com/mss-2-8-14.htm |title=The Marty Stuart Show \u2013 Episode 136 \u2013 February 8. 2014 |website=Martystuart.com |date=2014-02-08 |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> of ''The [[Marty Stuart]] Show''.\n* The band appeared in the documentary film ''[[The American Epic Sessions]]'' directed by [[Bernard MacMahon (filmmaker)|Bernard MacMahon]] and recorded \"[[Saint Louis Blues (song)|St. Louis Blues]]\" on the first [[History of sound recording#The electrical era (1925 to 1945) (including sound on film)|electrical sound recording]] system from the 1920s. The film premiered June 6, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.legacyrecordings.com/2017/04/28/american-epic-collection-american-epic-soundtrack-may-12th/|title=American Epic: The Collection & The Soundtrack Out May 12th {{!}} Legacy Recordings|date=2017-04-28|work=Legacy Recordings|access-date=2018-02-27|language=en-US}}</ref>\n*The band appeared on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' on August 17, 2017 and performed \"Better Man Than Me\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://teamcoco.com/video/pokey-lafarge-better-man-than-me-08/17/17 |title=Pokey LaFarge \"Better Man Than Me\" 08/17/17  |website=Teamcoco.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818214759/http://teamcoco.com/video/pokey-lafarge-better-man-than-me-08/17/17 |archive-date=2017-08-18}}</ref>\n*He appeared as \"Hank Snow\" in the 2017 \u2013 2018 CMT Television Series \"Sun Records\"<ref>{{Cite web|website=[[IMDb]] |title=Sun Records |date=2017-02-23 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5583410/?ref_=tt_ch |type=Biography, Drama, History |access-date=2022-10-27}}</ref>\n*He appeared as \"Theodore\" in the Netflix film ''[[The Devil All the Time (film)|The Devil All the Time]]'' and contributed to the soundtrack.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5765616/|title=Pokey LaFarge|website=[[IMDb]]}}</ref>\n\n==Musical style==\n\n\nThe group is thought to be \"artfully dodgy ambassadors for old-time music, presenting and representing the glories of hot swing, early jazz and ragtime blues\" who have \"made riverboat chic cool again.\"<ref name=\"Danielsen\">{{cite news|last=Danielsen|first=Aarik|title=Roots N Blues field guide: Pokey LaFarge and the South City Three|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/weblogs/art-axis/2012/sep/13/roots-n-blues-field-guide-pokey-lafarge-and-the-so/|access-date=14 September 2012|newspaper=Columbia Daily Tribune|date=September 13, 2012}}</ref>\n\n===Genre===\nHis repertoire consists of a mix of [[Americana (music)|Americana]], early [[jazz]], [[ragtime]] for string instruments, [[country blues]], [[Western swing]], [[Vaudeville]], and [[Appalachian music|Appalachian folk]].<ref name=\"DeYoung\"/>\n\n===Influences===\nMusicians that have influenced him include [[Howlin' Wolf]], [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]], [[Bill Monroe]], [[Milton Brown]] and the Musical Brownies, [[Modern Mountaineers]], [[Sleepy John Estes]], [[Henry Townsend (musician)|Henry Townsend]], [[Frank Fairfield]], [[Fats Waller]], [[Emmett Miller]], Marc Bolan, Peter Lafarge, and Willie Dixon.<ref name=\"Kasten\"/>\n\n== Personal ==\nLaFarge married singer [[Addie Hamilton]] in [[Camden, Maine]] on September 29th, 2023.\n\n==Members==\n===Current members===\n*Pokey LaFarge \u2013 lead vocals, guitar, [[guitjo (six-string)|guitjo]] (2006\u2013present)\n*Kevin Carducci \u2013 bass, harmony vocals (2021\u2013present)\n*Andrew Guterman \u2013 drums, harmony vocals (2021\u2013present)\n*Erik Miron \u2013 guitar, trumpet (2022\u2013present)\n*Hank Mehren \u2013 keyboard, organ (2022\u2013present)\n*Addie Hamilton \u2013 harmony vocals (2021\u2013present)\n\n===Former members===\n*Adam Hoskins \u2013 guitar (2009\u20132018)\n*Joey Glynn \u2013 upright bass (2008\u20132018)\n*[[Ryan Koenig]] \u2013 harmonica, washboard, guitar, guitjo, snare drum (2008\u20132018)\n*Matthew Meyer \u2013 drums (2014\u20132018)\n*[[Chloe Feoranzo]] \u2013 clarinet, saxophone (2013\u20132015)\n*Timothy Muller \u2013 trumpet, trombone (2013\u20132015)\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n* 2006: ''Marmalade'' (self-released)\n* 2008: ''Beat, Move, and Shake'' ([[Big Muddy Records|Big Muddy]])\n* 2010: ''Riverboat Soul'' ([[Free Dirt Records|Free Dirt]])\n* 2011: ''Middle of Everywhere'' (Free Dirt)\n* 2012: ''Live in Holland'' (Continental Song City)\n* 2013: ''Pokey LaFarge'' ([[Third Man Records|Third Man]])\n* 2015: ''Something in the Water'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]])\n* 2017: ''Manic Revelations'' (Rounder)\n* 2020: ''Rock Bottom Rhapsody'' (New West) (release date 4/10/20)\n* 2021: ''In the Blossom of Their Shade'' (New West) (released 10/15/2021)\n* 2024: '' Rhumba Country '' (New West) (released 5/10/24)\n\n===EPs and singles===\n* 2011: \"'Chittlin' Cookin' Time in Cheatham County'\" (Third Man)\n* 2013: \"Central Time/St. Louis Crawl\" (Third Man)\n* 2016: \"Goodbye, Barcelona\" b/w \"Blue Morning Lullaby\" (Rounder)\n* 2017: \"Riot in the Streets\" (Rounder)\n\n===Compilations and other appearances===\n* 2009: ''Face a Frowning World: An E.C. Ball Memorial Album'' (Track: \"Poor Old Country Lad\")\n* 2009: ''The White Belt'' (with Joe Manning) (Karate Body)\n* 2012: ''[[Blunderbuss (album)|Blunderbuss]]''- [[Jack White]] (Third Man) (Track \"I Guess I Should Go To Sleep\")\n* 2013: ''You Don't Know Me: Rediscovering Eddy Arnold ''-[[Eddy Arnold]] (Plowboy) (Track: \"Lovebug Itch\")\n* 2013: ''[[Boardwalk Empire]] Soundtrack Volume 2'' (AVKCO) (Track \"Lovesick Blues\")\n* 2017: ''[[Music from The American Epic Sessions: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]'' ([[LO-MAX Records|Lo-Max]]/[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]/[[Third Man Records|Third Man]]) (Tracks: \"[[Saint Louis Blues (song)|St. Louis Blues]]\" & \"Josephine\")\n\n==Honors, distinctions, and awards==\n*2011 Independent Music Awards: ''Riverboat Soul'' \u2013 Best Americana Album\n*2012 Independent Music Awards: ''Middle of Everywhere'' \u2013 Best Americana Album<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima/2012/11th-annual-independent-music-awards-winners-announced/ |title=11th Annual Independent Music Awards Winners Announced! |publisher=Independent Music Awards |date=2012-05-02 |access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>\n*2014 U-High Alumni Hall of Fame: Inducted by [[University High School (Normal)|University High School]] in [[Normal, Illinois]] at the U-High Alumni Association Awards and Recognition Program on 26 September 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uhigh.ilstu.edu/rssfeeds/1415/awardsprogram.pdf |title=U-High University Homecoming 2014 |publisher=Uhigh.ilstu.edu |access-date=2015-05-21}}</ref>\n*2015 ''Something in the Water'' was named one of Peter Jones' Best Folk Albums of 2015 in the Folk Department of [[WTJU]], [[University of Virginia]] radio station.<ref>{{cite web|title = Peter Jones' Best Folk Albums of 2015 \u2013 WTJU|url = http://www.wtju.net/peter-jones-2015/|website = WTJU|date = 2 January 2016|access-date = 2016-01-10|language = en-US}}</ref>\n* 2017 Ameripolitan Music Awards Western Swing Male \u2013 Winner\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://www.pokeylafarge.net/}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Lafarge, Pokey}}\n[[Category:1983 births]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass musicians]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass music groups]]\n[[Category:American street performers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Illinois]]\n[[Category:People from Bloomington, Illinois]]\n[[Category:People from Normal, Illinois]]\n[[Category:Musicians from St. Louis]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Missouri]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Illinois]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Missouri]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:Swing revival musicians]]\n[[Category:Third Man Records artists]]\n[[Category:Rounder Records artists]]\n[[Category:Western swing performers]]"}]}}}}
